Award.AwardTitle: Cypriniform Morphological Novelties: Origin, Performance, and Evolutionary Implications
Award.AbstractNarration:
PROJECT TITLE: Cyriniform Morphological Novelties: Origin, Performance, and Evolutionary Implications

PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR: Hernandez, L. Patricia

NSF Project #: IOS 1025845

Key innovations have long been of interest to evolutionary biologists since such innovations are causally related to adaptive radiations. Cypriniform fishes, which comprise approximately 25% of all freshwater fishes are characterized by a number of evolutionary innovations associated with feeding that may have led to their own adaptive radiation. Although cypriniform fishes comprise an enormous proportion of the freshwater biota relatively little is known about the feeding novelties that characterize this diverse group. This integrative project combines molecular developmental techniques, functional morphological approaches, and comparative methods to investigate the origin and ultimate evolutionary consequences of cypriniform morphological novelties. The different developmental mechanisms involved in the generation of these novelties will be investigated using molecular techniques. A number of experimental approaches (high-speed video, PIV, and XROMM) will be used to investigate functional implications of these feeding novelties. Finally comparative methods will be used to determine the role of correlated evolution in the diversification of certain families within cypriniforms. Results will: clarify the role of different developmental mechanisms in the origin of evolutionary novelty, detail performance implications of novelties that have resulted from different developmental mechanisms, and determine the role of correlated evolution in adaptive radiations. This evo-devo project is unique in examining novelty at several levels starting from a developmental genetic level, through performance, and ultimately to evolutionary consequences.
This project also has significant broader impacts including promoting careers in science, interdisciplinary training of all personnel, continued recruiting of underrepresented minorities, and training of K-12 teachers during summer research programs to do simple experiments using zebrafish. Results will be disseminated broadly at varied scientific meetings, university presentations, and an established series of lectures to elementary school students. High-speed videos, as well as developmental techniques, will be available via online sources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Cypriniform fishes are a huge group of freshwater fishes, made up of nearly 4000 species and characterized by several feeding novelties that have likely played an important role in the evolutionary success of this group. The work supported by this grant was highly integrative and combined functional morphology, developmental biology, and evolutionary biology in investigating the feeding novelties that characterize cypriniform fishes. These novelties include a novel cranial bone (kinethmoid) that allows these fish to greatly protrude their jaws, greatly enlarged teeth in their throat, and a tongue-like structure on the roofs of their mouths used during feeding. The PI examined the role of the kinethmoid in a novel type of suction feeding. This work treated the skeletal anatomy within this group as an engineering problem, examining the functional implications of adding linkages to the mechanics of this system. While there were certain similarities with other suction feeding fishes that of cypriniforms showed a flexibility that increased the number of feeding behaviors that could be used, ultimately increasing the number of ecological niches that could be filled by this group.

Major discoveries within the functional morphological work included a deeper understanding of the biomechanical implications of a convergent mechanism of jaw protrusion that characterizes cypriniform fishes. We used two recently created technologies to address these functional questions. Specifically, we used both Digital Particle Image Velocimetry (DPIV) as well as X-ray Reconstruction of Moving Morphology (XROMM) to determine exactly how jaw protrusion differed in these independently derived biomechanical mechanisms. We found that while there was a basic convergence in the hydrodynamics of suction feeding using either evolutionary solution of the protrusile mechanism, there was a pronounced performance advantage associated with the form of suction feeding used by cypriniforms.

Our work on silver carp, a major area of focus during the final years of funding, has led to several important discoveries explaining how this invasive species is so effective in filter feeding. While this species is destroying biodiversity within North American rivers and threatening to enter and decimate ecosystems within the Great Lakes, there has been relatively little work examining the feeding anatomy of this species. The PI is continuing work on this important invasive species which may lead to ways of mitigating the ecological damage this species is responsible for.

The kinethmoid, the cranial element responsible for this increased flexibility in feeding modes, develops from a sesamoid cartilage. Much like our kneecaps these types of bones develop within tendons and ligaments. While it is often assumed that functional changes follow changes in anatomy, in the case of sesamoids the changes in the force regimes experienced by ligaments and tendons can bring about changes in anatomical structures, which can then have profound performance effects on subsequent morphological evolution within any given lineage. This flipping of cause and effect was an important discovery within this project and may inform us about how complex systems can evolve.

Broader Impacts: This grant has supported educational and research experiences for 9 undergraduates, 3 Master’s students, 1 postdoctoral fellow, and 6 doctoral students. This work also played an important role in the use of X-ray Reconstruction of Moving Morphology, a new technology that allows scientists to visualize real time, 3D movements of skeletal elements within live animals performing behaviors of interest within aquatic environments. Anatomy of the filtering plates of silver carp may serve as biomimetic inspiration for commercial filtering uses. This work also resulted in contributions to an open access encyclopedia of fish anatomy. The PI was actively involved in several types of outreach with minority populations throughout the course of this work. The PI also played a significant role in increasing diversity within the STEM fields through inclusion of several underrepresented groups, including those with learning disabilities.
